summary: In this adaptation of the autobiography "The Pianist: The Extraordinary True Story of One Man's Survival in Warsaw, 1939-1945," Wladyslaw Szpilman (Adrien Brody), a Polish Jewish radio station pianist, sees Warsaw change gradually as World War II begins. Szpilman is forced into the Warsaw Ghetto, but is later separated from his family during Operation Reinhard. From this time until the concentration camp prisoners are released, Szpilman hides in various locations among the ruins of Warsaw.

A gripping tale that's brutal and unapologetic when covering the Holocaust and the cruel prejudice towards Jews. Roman Polansky creates such a personal tale by connecting us with Szpilman and by allowing us to see his highs and lows it creates an underdog story that everyone can root for, and it's helped even further through Adrien Brody's phenomenal performance. I'm glad that the topic isn't censored or watered down from the truth, as an authentic experience of the Jews treatment is necessary just to open your eyes to how bad the Holocaust was, and how cruel man can be towards each other. Whilst it's admittedly slow at times, the pacing matches the tempo of the story since hiding would be a tedious and boring activity, but it's able to always keep you engaged and alert with Red Herrings of danger and the fear of closing both eyes whilst sleeping. However, the first half is definitely the stronger part of the story, as most of the second half involved time leaps and the aforementioned naturally slow pacing. There's also a cyclical and ironic effect created through the film, as whilst the Jews are herded like Cattle and caged in Ghettos and Camps, by the end of the film the Russians enslave the Nazi's in PoW camps, and the whole full circle sense of Karma is really felt. The only thing honestly keeping me from despising the cruelness of humanity was the one outlier in the Nazi who helped keep Szpilman safe and fed, the one proof that even in the worst of times, there's always a shred of hope left.

I’m just going to bite the bullet and say something that is potentially quite ugly and offensive, so I’ll apologize in advance for how this makes me sound. I’ve seen enough of the Holocaust. I know it was probably the ugliest and most horrendous moments in humanity’s history. I know that Nazis did unspeakably awful things to Jews. I know that life for anyone Jewish was unbearable, for however long they could keep their lives. But over the years I’ve seen so many films on the subject, my emotional reserves have been used up. I couldn’t muster a tear for Wladyslaw Szpilman’s struggle, and almost feel like I’ve become desensitized to scenes of Jews being carted off to concentration camps or shot in the streets. My brain still sees the horror and hates that this was reality, but my heart has been drowned in similar shots in countless movies to the point where it can’t continue to break every time I see it. In fact, I just watched a couple of similar films based on the true stories of Jews fleeing the Holocaust within the last month, so perhaps it was just bad timing. I think the other reason that The Pianist didn’t connect with me as well as any number of similar stories is the passive role that Szpilman plays in his own story. In many ways he is merely an observer of what happens. His story is about fleeing, watching, and others helping him. Once his family is removed from the equation, we don’t form much of a bond with anyone else we see suffering. I’m not suggesting he did anything wrong, in fact his story is quite impressive. However, when I’ve seen films about people inside the concentration camps, or forced to endure heinous acts of cruelty, it’s hard to be as impacted by a guy who is hiding. I hope this doesn’t make me sound too much like a monster, and I certainly didn’t hate The Pianist. In fact, I was looking forward to hearing him play more, because the actual music was marvelous. It’s impossible to be bored by a movie like this, because there’s always some new horrible thing around the corner. I guess my standards for movies in this genre have just been raised too much, and it will take something truly original or outstanding to hit me with the power of Holocaust movies that came before.

Roman Rolanski's historical drama epic The Pianist (2002) is a remarkably sympathetic story about one Polish pianist and composer named Wladyslaw Szpilman, who must survive The Holocaust and World War II as a Jewish man. The story is riveting and devastating with so much death and destruction like you cannot imagine. Polanski's direction is sobering with no glorification of violence in his action, but rather a somber depiction of mass death and unreal cruelty that Polish Jews faced at the hands of German Nazis. Polanski is a controversial figure and a repulsive man, but he is a stalwart director of gripping visual prowess and The Pianist is a definitive film within his illustrious cinematic career. The Pianist will make you feel traumatized at the sheer volume of the dead, hungry with pangs that you cannot sate, and sad for all the lost lives stolen by ruthless Germans.

Adrien Brody is the reason to bear witness on The Pianist as he is a revelation of humanistic acting. His realism is so tragic and hard to watch. He brings a genuine likable personality alongside a deeply nuanced role as a man desperate to survive. His shaking gaunt body, limp walking gait, fluent linguistics, emotionally distraught eyes, and trembling voice all make him a riveting lead actor. Brody earnest his Oscar for Best Lead Actor several times over in The Pianist. He is simply a marvelous representation of how real a performance can come across. He finds a heart in the musical backdrop of The Pianist to keep him going and Brody is hypnotizing as he searches for food, often in vain, for any module of crumb to consume.

The score to The Pianist is breathtaking like the visuals of ruined cities and crumbled over corpses. You are mesmerized by masterful piano playing as the classical compositions gracefully cover all the bloodshed and agony throughout The Pianist. You are given a moment's reprieve from all the sorrow every time a song is played on piano during The Pianist.

In all, you should watch The Pianist because it is an important and shocking depiction of real life human atrocities carried out by cruel bloodthirsty Germans. Also Roman Polanski's direction is steadfast with a focus on the human moments of pain, disgust, hunger, confusion, fear, cruelty, compassion, empathy, and hope. The Pianist is so effectively moving and engrossing that Polanski makes a two and a half hour long film feel like only one. Adrien Brody's transformation into a Holocaust survivor alone is worth seeing as he keeps you on edge with every word.

Obviously the fact that Roman Polanski directed the film attaches some controversy to it as it does seem unfair that somebody who committed horrible acts is able to direct such a large and acclaimed production. If you separate art from the artist you will be capable of appreciating this film and it's many wonderful components.

Successful Jewish pianist Wladyslaw Szpilman, Adrien Brody, witnesses growing anti-Semitism in Warsaw, Poland in 1939 as his family disagree over the approach they should take in facing this increasing threat. His celebrity keeps him safe as Jews are forced into ghettos and brutally punished for no reason. He is separated from his family when they are sent away to death camps while he is left behind in Warsaw, one of a few Jews who work as bricklayers. With his situation worsening he is forced into hiding and he relies on Dorota, Emilia Fox, a Polish woman he knew before conditions worsened to keep him safe in hiding. Through this all he retains his desire to play the piano and after the city becomes even more devastated and he hides in the wreckage of the ghetto he puts his talents to good use. After the Russians arrive to take back control of Poland he regains his freedom and is able to play the piano on the radio again.

The film is able to display the harrowing experience of being a Jew during this period through brief moments of senseless violence and sheer ruthlessness from Nazi oppressors who lose all humanity under a terrifying system. At several points we see large groups of random, innocent Jews executed for asking simple questions the Nazis or standing at the wrong point in a lineup. We are terrified by these scenes as we understand how wrong this situation is but we also see what luck Szpilman had in surviving and how the system destroyed the lives of the innocent. Viewing this tragedy through the eyes of a person who had no real political agenda and survived as a result of luck, and extraordinary resilience, not some grand scheme that made him better than the average person. The victims of the holocaust were regular, well meaning similar to civilians all around the world and making Szpilman an everyman figure of sorts leads us to identify with him more than we do with Sophie Zawistowski or Nelly Dreifuss.

There is power also in the impressive production values as the costumes, musical score and sheer scope of the film blow you away. Polanski is clearly a masterful director and he paces the film nicely as we get a sense of the escalating tensions occurring in Poland and the increasing desperation that Szpilman feels in addition to knowing how much time has passed. Anchoring the film is the soulful performance from Brody who earned an Academy Award for his efforts and considerable clout. Suffering and desperation are a common theme in award winning performances but Brody is equally convincing as the man willing to let intolerance from others slide in order to simply play his piano. The supporting cast put in fine performances with Frank Finlay and Maureen Lipman being expectedly brilliant as his beaten down parents. Whether or not he is good man it cannot be denied that Polanski knows how to get the best out of everyone he works with, Pirates (1986) excepted.

Although I have a lot of positive things to say about the film I would say it occasionally lacks in dramatic tension as long scenes of Brody starving and nobly suffering stretch on for far too long. These are minor complaints as the film as a whole is a satisfying and consistently interesting cinematic experience but sadly I struggle to call the film a masterpiece because for all it's weighty and important themes and technical brilliance it doesn't quite connect emotionally but it is still absolutely worth viewing.

Roman Polanski steadily directs The Pianist about a Polish piano player who successfully eluded the Nazis for five years in Warsaw, Poland.  Naturally acted, beautifully shot, leisurely paced and convincingly realistic, The Pianist is one of the most mature holocaust-related films ever.  The soundtrack is soothing, the clothing/set design is authentic for the time period and the story is immersive as we follow the protagonist in his struggle to survive and fear of getting captured.

Divisive director Roman Polanski has had a polarizing career both behind camera and in a personnel sense yet whatever one may feel about the man or the filmmaker there is little doubt that his most effective and most profound movie is 2002's The Pianist. A true life war tale of incredible determination and bravery, Polanski's telling of accomplished Poland pianist and Jew Wladyslaw Szpilman ranks as one of cinemas greatest War set tales thanks to an incredibly realistic feel and a raft of award worthy acting turns.

Justifiably winning Polanski a Best Director Oscar, The Pianist sees the veteran director at his highest creative peak, an artist moulding with his material perfectly to create a vividly alive look into the atrocities that faced Warsaw's Jewish community and all others of similar creeds during Hitler's reign of terror. Polanski's Warsaw is brimming with stark images, from bodies strewn in the streets of the Jewish "ghettos", snow covered buildings in the harsh reality of a European winter and the strange comforts of an upmarket café as people go hungry outside, it's unquestionable that the setting of The Pianist is a character unto itself and part of the reason the movie works to the extent it does. It's interesting also to note how many a time Polanski films some of the movies most confronting scenes (wheelchair bound elders thrown from windows etc.) from a wide shot perspective, giving us the viewers a feeling of witnessing these events from far, powerless to stop what is happening yet not to the extent of being unaffected by it, much like our protagonist Wladyslaw Szpilman.

It would be remiss now with a decade hindsight of Adrien Brody to not remark on the power he displayed here as Szpilman. Brody inhabits Szpilman to an extent you quickly forget it is an actor you are watching, whether he is brave, scared or as time wears on dangerously gaunt, Brody delivers the Oscar winning turn that seemingly set him up for an illustrious career that so far has sadly failed to eventuate. It's impossible to say with full assurance that it's Brody's fault completely that he has failed to get close creatively to what he delivered here in Polanski's effort or if it is filmmakers that have failed him in their material. Whatever the case may be regarding Brody's disappointing post-Pianist career there is no taking away from his ageless performance here in an ensemble that all play their parts to perfection from Frank Finlay as Szpilman's aging father through to Thomas Kretschmann's small but pivotal role as German captain Wilm Hosenfeld.

A heartening tale of survival, an indictment of the horrors of war and the evil within humanity, The Pianist is not always an easy watch but it's an important one. A truly stunning tale of the will to survive and a tension filled 2 and a half hours thanks to Polanski's no fuss professional turn behind camera, this is true life based storytelling at its finest and a worthy film to sit alongside other revered War based film classics.

Review In A Nutshell:

Another film, hurt by the established hype and acclaim from critics and general audiences, hoping that the film would deliver more than what any other film has not already done. Many have rejoiced Roman Polanski's The Pianist as a World War 2 masterpiece exploring one man's resilience and determination to survive, which are common but effective themes to explore but Polanski and screenwriter Ronald Harwood couldn't bring anything unique or with intense emotional impact to an already exhaustive concept.

The film spends the bulk of its first and second act, following Wladyslaw Szpilman and the significant aspect of his life that he has lost. I felt that Harwood and Polanski could have added a couple of scenes that would show the personal impact of his losses. It was clear within the first 20 minutes of the film that he is deeply attached to his art and family; shouldn't the film instead explore this if Polanski aims to create a personal and intimate experience? Also, I felt the film did not explore or emphasise enough, the protagonist's need to adapt to this sudden change of lifestyle; very few scenes show the natural fear and anxiety that one would feel when placed in a similar situation. That being said, I was not at all bored watching this aspect of the film, as there were some moments where drama was exquisitely crafted, without reaching extreme levels of sentimentality. The film's strongest area resides on its final act, where we actually get to see some growth from the character and shows the audience that this man is determined to survive and can somehow do so without relying too much on others. The film also shows a subtle and effective relationship between our protagonist and a German soldier; I will not give away the fruits of these moments as seeing them displayed a side of the film and Polanski, that I never knew had the potential to achieve. The final act also finally emphasises the impact that his passion for playing the piano or composing music has had on him since the war; I only wish that the film touched on it much earlier, instead of saturating it during the final moments of the film.

In all of his films, Polanski has given his films a subtle but distinctive visual or technical style to further spotlight the themes that are being explored or achieve an atmosphere that would either reflect intrinsic shadings of his characters, Rosemary's Baby, or simply to create effective tension, Frantic, or beauty, Tess. The Pianist sadly felt visually flat, lacking emphasis in its cinematography. The film is certainly ambitious in its production design, displaying the catastrophic destruction of Warsaw and the aching disintegration of its social structure; but the lack of artistic expression in its photography prevented the film from seeming visually perfect.

The performances in this film were, however, consistently strong with Adrien Brody playing this character, not revealing too much of his role's internal qualities through forced emotions or dialogue, instead relying it under the masterful hand of Roman Polanski. The director knew exactly what he wanted from Brody and he successfully was able to bring it out of him, which is something that Brody has not been able to do with other directors.

The Pianist does not possess the same emotional and humanitarian substance of Schindler's List or the social, cultural and physical destruction or disintegration of Children of Men; but it does provide enough to sit through with its ideas of survival, loss, and resiliency, and of course, Adrien Brody's performance.

In all of his films, Polanski has given his films a subtle but distinctive visual or technical style to further spotlight the themes that are being explored or achieve an atmosphere that would either reflect intrinsic shadings of his characters, Rosemary's Baby, or simply to create effective tension, Frantic, or beauty, Tess. The Pianist sadly felt visually flat, lacking emphasis in its cinematography. The film is certainly ambitious in its production design, displaying the catastrophic destruction of Warsaw and the aching disintegration of its social structure; but the lack of artistic expression in its photography prevented the film from seeming visually perfect.

The performances in this film were, however, consistently strong with Adrien Brody playing this character, not revealing too much of his role's internal qualities through forced emotions or dialogue, instead relying it under the masterful hand of Roman Polanski. The director knew exactly what he wanted from Brody and he successfully was able to bring it out of him, which is something that Brody has not been able to do with other directors.

The Pianist does not possess the same emotional and humanitarian substance of Schindler's List or the social, cultural and physical destruction or disintegration of Children of Men; but it does provide enough to sit through with its ideas of survival, loss, and resiliency, and of course, Adrien Brody's performance.

Based on the autobiography of classical pianist Wladyslaw Szpilman (Adrien Brody), a Polish Jew who survived the Warsaw ghetto during the Nazi occupation. Among the non-documentary features made about the Holocaust, this is the most emotionally restrained and morally complex examination of the day-to-day struggle for survival. We see the consequences of how war causes individuals to become collaborators, profiteers, or members of the resistance.  Director Roman Polanski's movies are notorious for depicting a pessimistic worldview but this is his most personal and hopeful movie to date. (Polanski survived the Krakow ghetto while his mother perished in a concentration camp.) Szpilman is a passive hero but this is not a passive movie. Storytelling momentum fades near the end but it remains captivating. Ronald Harwood adapted the memoir. Cinematography is by Pawl Edelman; Music is by Wojciech Kilar. The picture took the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival and won Oscars for Best Actor (Adrien Brody), Best Director, and Best Adapted Screenplay.
